ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to read literature through a feminist a queer lens

The course takes a somewhat-deep dive into Professor Homans' interests in feminist and queer theory, specifically focusing on what it means to be a reader, the different methods and epistemologies of reading/interpreting, and how those relate to our own lives (we all exist as subjects! We all interpret, cope with the past, and project a future in every moment of our lives). My writing definitely improved a lot. Professor Homans' comments are always very deep and truly engaged in the arguments that her students make in essays. I would often learn new things or realize possible holes in my theories by reading the marginal comments she left as notes. Even though she's a very thorough grader, she's not a difficult one - please take this course if you're interested in queer/feminist theory and thinking personally about what those terms might mean for you as a student/writer of literature!
I felt like I gained a solid foundational knowledge of feminist and queer literary criticism and how to apply it to various texts.

I learned so much from Professor Homans! What a wonderful class - this was my first methods course, and I was exposed to so much theory and literary criticism. This class broadened my reading and writing skills, as well as my approach to understanding history/positionality/identity in the world.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was really fantastic. The only criticism I have is that sometimes our discussions would get quiet or grow a little bit vague because Professor Homans would lead us into some very big-question thinking rather than the specifics of the texts/theories we were meant to focus on for that seminar. But that might be a plus for some students - it definitely led to some awkward moments for us this semester, but it also helped me expand my way of thinking through the topics presented by the authors read in the course.

The syllabus was structured in a way that helped put the texts in conversation, so all of the ideas we talked about stayed relevant throughout the course. That said, I think having some more primary texts scattered throughout would have helped some of the stretches of theory feel a little less abstract.

Professor Homans is a BIG STRENGTH of the class. She is brilliant, approachable, very supportive, and so generous with her feedback. For my final paper, she literally sent me a page of comments !! Another strength is the rigorous, diverse, and rich syllabus of reading. 

No weaknesses besides virtual seminar format due to pandemic.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Since the class was pretty small, Zoom meetings were the closest we could get to seminar meetings, and Prof. Homans did a really good job of trying to keep people engaged. I think that the weirdness of Zoom just made discussions a little less robust than they would have been in person.
I thought Professor Homans made the seminar as engaging as possible under pandemic conditions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! A great class that makes you think.

Yes! Take the course if you're interested in queer/feminist theory or in learning about cool, "meta" aspects of reading/literature/interpretation and how they relate to personhood, or about the political/practical as well as lofty implications of certain forms of literature.

YES! Take this class. There are not very many methods classes available, and even fewer that focus on feminist/queer literary criticism and theory. I was really impressed with the syllabus, Professor Homans' constant re-interrogation of the course structure, and the comments of my peers!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was a virtual seminar! We also met once at the end of the semester.

extras.title:
ENGL 259 01/WGSS 352 01
        Feminist and Queer Lit Methods
